abstracts.cdata!:
The African member countries of the
            Franc zone decided to devalue their currency, the CFA franc,
            effective January 12, 1994. The Economic Recovery Credit
            Project will support the post-devaluation reform program as
            outlined in the government's Statement of Economic and
            Social Policy, and, more particularly, the measures aimed at
            minimizing the negative social impact of the devaluation in
            the short-term; and to provide the necessary financial
            assistance during the transition period in which follow-up
            operations are being prepared to support further structural
            and sectoral reforms. The Nigerian government has already
            taken a series of key macroeconomic and structural measures
            to regain and consolidate competitiveness. The credit is
            designed to support the implementation of these measures in
            1994. The major measures are: (a) the devaluation of the CFA
            franc from 50 CFAF to 100 CFAF/1 FF; (b) tax measures to
            increase fiscal revenue; (c) a substantial program of social
            measures to attenuate the effects of the devaluation on
            vulnerable groups, including increasing significantly in
            real terms current expenditure for health and education; (d)
            prudent demand management policies to reduce absorption by
            the public sector and limit wage increases; and (e)
            reduction of external tariffs.
